1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Kazakhstan  for  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic Cooperation  (CAREC) 
Corridor 1 (Taraz Bypass) Project.1 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

2. 
The project will develop a 65-kilometer (km) road section in Taraz of Zhambyl Oblast in 
Kazakhstan, which is part of the Government of Kazakhstan’s priority Western Europe–Western 
People’s  Republic  of  China  Corridor  Investment  Program.  The  investment  program  aims  to 
improve  approximately  2,787  km  of  road  sections  in  Kazakhstan  along  CAREC  Corridor  1, 
running  from  Khorgos  through  Almaty  and  Shymkent  to  the  Russian  Federation's  western 
border. When  the  investment  program  is  completed  in  2015,  the  corridor  is  expected  to  more 
efficiently carry increasing international traffic. 

3. 
The project is compatible with the CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy and 
Action Plan,2 and the core business areas of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Kazakhstan. 

4. 
The  investment  program  has  been  smoothly  implemented  since  its  start  in  2009,  with 
assistance  from  international  financial  institutions.  The  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development is financing a 102 km road section and the World Bank a 1,062 km road section. 
The Islamic Development Bank (IDB), the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and 
ADB  committed  to  improving  a  480  km  section  in  Zhambyl  Oblast  through  the  investment 
program.3 Specifically, ADB committed to finance approximately 301 km through a multitranche 
financing  facility  (MFF)  not  exceeding  $700  million,4 IDB  committed  to  finance  159  km,5 and 
JICA 20 km. 

5. 
Since  2008,  ADB  has  provided  four  loans  totaling  $697  million  under  the  MFF,  which 
financed improvement of approximately 351 km of road sections;6 IDB provided a $170 million 
loan in 2009 for 57 km; and JICA provided a $68 million loan in 2010 for 20 km. 

6. 
Financial  issues  caused  IDB  to  withdraw  in  2010  its  earlier  commitment  to  finance 
improvement of two remaining sections, totaling 114 km, which the government then requested 
that ADB finance. The seamless completion of all road sections in Zhambyl Oblast is crucial for 
the success of the investment program, and consequently ADB approved, with available funds

 under  the  existing  MFF,  a  $112  million  loan  in  February  2011  as  tranche  4  of  the  MFF  to 
improve a 49 km portion of IDB’s former 114 km section.7 It is now proposed that ADB provide a 
separate loan of $95 million to improve the 65 km Taraz bypass (the remaining portion of IDB’s 
former section), as the MFF has been fully utilized.  

7. 
The 65 km Taraz bypass section is integral to the transport corridor, connecting the oil-
rich  western  part  of  the  country  to  southeast  Kazakhstan  and  beyond.  The  project  will  boost 
regional connectivity and strengthen the viability of the investment program roads. 

8. 
Kazakhstan's  93,600  km  road  network  includes  23,495  km  of  republican  (national  and 
international) roads, with the rest being rural and urban roads. Road freight traffic has increased 
as  a  result  of  growth  in  vehicular  traffic  and  private  road-hauling  companies,  shorter  transport 
hauls of goods compared to other modes of transport, and a changing industrial and distribution 
pattern. In 2009, roads accounted for 25% of Kazakhstan's freight traffic by ton-km and 85% of 
its  passenger  traffic  by  passenger-km.  These  shares  are  likely  to  continue  to  grow  in  the 
foreseeable future. 

9. 
Kazakhstan’s road sector has operational and institutional bottlenecks, caused mainly by 
(i)  insufficient  and  deteriorating  infrastructure,  (ii)  weak  cost  recovery,  (iii) inefficient  cross-
border  procedures,  (iv)  weak  planning,  and  (v)  limited  project  development  and  management 
capacity.  These  bottlenecks  raise  transport  costs  and  hamper  regional  cooperation  and 
integration  opportunities,  undercutting  the  country’s  competitiveness.  Based  on  the  lessons 
learned,  ADB  realized  that  sufficient  support  for  institutional  capacity  development  throughout 
the duration of the projects has to be sustained. This is further described under implementation 
arrangements (para. 15). 

10.  Much of the road network is in poor condition, as 40% of republican roads require major 
rehabilitation and proper maintenance. The feeder road network serving the rural population is 
not fully developed. Roads on the six main international corridors are mostly paved with asphalt, 
but  their  technical  and  operational  characteristics  (e.g.,  evenness  and  strength)  are  below 
international standards, with current traffic often exceeding allowable loads. 

The  government  has  adopted  the  2020  Strategy  for  Economic  Development  and  the 
11. 
State  Program  on  Accelerated  Industrial-Innovative  Development  (SPAID)  to  diversify  the 
economy  and  promote  balanced  developments.  To  effectively  support  the  2020  Strategy  and 
SPAID,  the  government  reshaped  and  expanded  its  previous  road  development  plan  into  the 
Transport  Sector  Program  (TSP)  for  2010–2014.8 The  TSP  will  develop  an  efficient  transport 
system that is integrated into the international transport network. The project aligns with ADB's 
Strategy 2020,9 its country operations business plan for 2010–2011,10 and Kazakhstan's SPAID 
and TSP.

2 

 

 B. 

Impact and Outcome 

12. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  regional  cooperation  and  trade  in  Kazakhstan  by  helping 
the  economy  better  integrate  into  the  global  economy.  The  outcome  will  ensure  better 
connectivity for the Zhambyl Oblast section of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1. 

C. 

Outputs 

The  outputs  will  be  (i)  an  approximate  7.7  km  upgraded  road,  from  category-II  to 
13. 
category-IB with four lanes; and (ii) an approximate 57.4 km new category-II bypass road. The 
upgrading  of  the  existing  7.7  km  section  will  be  undertaken  within  the  existing  right-of-way; 
construction of the 57.4 km bypass will require land acquisition. 

Investment and Financing Plans 

D. 
 
14. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $123  million  equivalent,  inclusive  of  taxes  and  duties. 
The government has requested a loan of $95 million from ADB to help finance the project. The 
government will finance the balance. The loan, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, will have 
a  24-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  4  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment  charge of  0.15%  per  year (the  interest  and other  charges  during construction  will 
not  be  capitalized  in  the  loan  and  will  be  paid  separately  by  the  government),  and such  other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The government has provided ADB 
with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based 
on  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own 
independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any  communication  or  advice  from  ADB.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

15. 
The  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Communications  (MOTC)  will  be  the  executing  agency 
and  the  Committee  of  Roads  under  MOTC  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  The  program 
management  unit  (PMU)  within  the  Committee  of  Roads  is  in  charge  of  four  ongoing  MFF 
projects,  assisted  by  the  program  management  consultants,  and  will  manage  this  project.11 
Following  a  capacity  assessment  mission  in  July  2011,  it  was  determined  that  additional 
resources—particularly safeguard, procurement, and contracts specialists staff—will be needed 
to support the PMU in managing projects. These additional resources will be engaged under the 
tranche 1 loan (Loan 2503-KAZ) (footnote 4). MOTC has also planned for additional staff at the 
oblast  level.  The  terms  of  reference  of  the  supervision  consulting  firm  engaged  under  the 
tranche 4 project (Loan 2735-KAZ) are sufficiently broad to enable it to provide supervision and 
safeguards  implementation  management  for  this  project.  Therefore,  sufficient  additional 
resources  have  been  planned  to  address  overall  management  and supervision  of  this  project. 
Sufficient  funds  are  available  under  the  respective  loans  mentioned  to  finance  the  additional 
scope. The  implementation  arrangements  are summarized  in Table 3  and  further  described in 
the project administration manual (PAM).12

 A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The  65  km  road  section  will  pass  through  the  Baisak  and  Zhambyl  administrative 
16. 
subdivisions (rayons) of Zhambyl Oblast. The 7.7 km section between km 483 and km 491 will 
be upgraded to technical category IB, situated at the edge of Taraz City. The remaining 57.4 km 
section  between  km  491  and  km  536  (a  two-lane  bypass  road  around  Taraz  City)  will  be 
constructed to technical category II specifications. The project involves (i) widening the 7.7 km 
section from a two- to four-lane road with a center mall, and (ii) constructing a 57.4 km two-lane 
bypass for a design speed of 120 km per hour. All traffic lanes and shoulders on both sides will 
be  3.75  meters  wide.  The  65  km  sections  will  be  paved  with  asphalt.  The  right-of-way  is 
designed with a 200-meter buffer zone to keep the alignment away from the archaeological sites 
in  the  surrounding  area.  Crossing  two  rivers,  the  alignment  will  include  two  bridges,  four 
interchanges,  and  railway  overpasses  paved  with  asphalt  concrete.  The  detailed  design  is 
complete including the preparation of the civil works bidding documents. 

B. 

Economic and Financial 

17. 
The project will contribute to achieving the envisaged benefits of the improved transport 
corridor: higher travel speeds, shortened travel distances, and improved road safety standards. 
The  economic  evaluation  of  the  project  was  undertaken  using  ADB's Guidelines  for  Economic 
Analysis of Projects.13 The economic analysis compares the with- and without-project scenarios. 
The  methodology  and  general  approach  to  the  economic  evaluation  involved  updating  the 
previous  due  diligence  work  carried  out  when  the  four  Zhambyl  Oblast  road  sections  were 
originally  analyzed,  individually  and  collectively,  to  prepare  the  (subsequently  approved) 
CAREC  Transport  Corridor  I  Investment  Program.  The  construction  costs  and  disbursement 
program have been updated, as well as values of time, vehicle operating cost, and time savings. 
The economic costs are (i) capital, including physical contingencies but excluding taxes; and (ii) 
operation  and  maintenance,  including  replacing  of  depreciated  equipment.  The  economic 
benefits are (i) savings in vehicle operating costs resulting from the improved project road, and 
(ii)  time  savings.  The  neighboring  road  sections  remain  under  construction,  and  traffic  on  the 
project road therefore remains unchanged. Using the 2009 average daily traffic volumes, annual 
normal traffic growth was forecast at 4% for 2010–2014, and 6% thereafter.  Generated traffic, 
estimated  as  10%–30%  of  normal  traffic,  was  included  in  the  analysis.  The  project  is 
economically  feasible  with  an  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  13.5%.  Sensitivity 
tests confirmed the project would remain feasible should the envisaged project costs increase, 
or benefits be reduced. No financial analysis was undertaken because the project road will not 
generate any revenues. 

C. 

Governance 

18. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and MOTC. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are  described  in  the  PAM  (footnote  12).  The  government’s  policies  and  procedures  regarding 
financial management and procurement have been assessed and found to be lacking in some 
areas.  The  additional  resources  described  under  implementation  arrangements  (para.  15)  will 
be mobilized to manage and monitor compliance with these policies and procedures. 

                                                
13  ADB. 1997. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila.   

5 

 

 All bidding documents for the civil works contract will include provisions specifying ADB’s 
19. 
right to audit the committee’s records and accounts related to the project, as well as those of all 
contractors, suppliers, and other service providers as they relate to the project. Key measures to 
ensure  proper governance  are (i) independent  external  auditing  of  contracts,  project  accounts, 
and financial statements; (ii) transparent decision processes for all procurement matters; and (iii) 
verification  of  contractors’  payment  claims  by  the  supervising  consultant  and  oversight  by  the 
PMU. 

D. 

Poverty and Social 

20. 
The  average per  capita income of Zhambyl  Oblast  is  one  of the  lowest  in Kazakhstan. 
The  main  economic  activities  in  the  project  area  are  agriculture,  and  livestock  and  poultry 
raising.  The  project  is  expected  to  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  by  stimulating  economic 
activities  by  improving  the  transport  of  goods  and  people  and  access  to  services.  The  project 
will  also  benefit  local  residents  and  enterprises  by  creating  jobs  during  construction  and 
reducing  transport  cost  and  travel  time.  Social  and  poverty  assessments  are  shown  in  the 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy.14 

21. 
The  project  is  classified  as  a  general  intervention,  with  no  direct  poverty  reduction 
component.  It  will  benefit  poor  people  in the  project  area  by  improving transport  conditions for 
better access to social services. The project will create some job opportunities for women during 
implementation and after project completion, apart from the benefits described above. 

22. 
The  civil  works  contract  will  require  that  contractors  (i)  comply  with  Kazakhstan’s 
applicable labor laws and related international treaty obligations and not employ child labor; (ii) 
provide safe working conditions and separate sanitation facilities for male and female workers; 
(iii)  provide  equal  wages  to  male  and  female  workers  for  work  of  equal  value;  (iv)  provide 
employment  opportunities  for  women;  and  (v)  carry  out  HIV/AIDS,  illicit  drugs,  and  human 
trafficking prevention and awareness programs in workers’ campsites. 

E. 

Safeguards 

1. 

Environment 

 
23. 
The project is classified as environment category A. MOTC prepared the environmental 
impact  assessment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009). 15  Major 
anticipated  environmental  impacts  relate  to  construction  of  bridges,  railway  overpasses, 
interchanges,  and  cutting  ―non-special  status‖  trees.  The  alignment  has  been  designed  to 
ensure it does not encroach on archeological sites. Adequate mitigation measures are included 
in,  and  will  be  implemented  through,  the  environmental  management  plan.  The  environmental 
management  plan  stipulates  that  capacity  development  be  provided  for  MOTC  and  its 
consultants  through  training  workshops  at  the  preconstruction  and  construction  stages.  The 
project  management  consultants  (para.  15)  will  supplement  the  PMU  in  managing  the 
environmental  impacts  of  the  project,  including  through  capacity  development.  The  project 
complies with public disclosure and consultation requirements.

 2. 

Involuntary Resettlement 

 
24. 
The  project  is  classified  as  involuntary  resettlement  category  B.  Some  98  households 
and 10 legal entities will be affected by the project, but most impacts are expected to be minor, 
with no households displaced under the project. Only five households will lose more than 10% 
of their land. Some 214 hectares of land will be acquired for permanent use, most of which (188 
hectares) are leased on a long-term basis for agricultural use. 

According to ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, the government has revised its earlier 
25. 
draft  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  (LARP),  which  was  prepared  under IDB financing. 
The final LARP includes adequate provisions for additional compensation for termination of land 
leases  and  for  assistance  for  the  severely  affected  households.  The  original  LARP  was 
disclosed to displaced persons during several public consultations in 2009–2011, and brochures 
in Russian and Kazak were distributed. The original LARP was partially implemented in 2009 as 
part  of  the  preparation  for  IDB  financing.  Consultations  on  the  final  LARP  were  held  with

compensation  payments  amounting  to  T8.4  million,  to  be  funded  by  the  government,  are 
expected  to  be  completed  by  December  2011.  Completion  of  LARP  implementation  is  a 
condition  for  starting  civil  works.  The  government  will  ensure  that  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  activities  comply  with  all  applicable  laws  and  regulations  of  the  borrower  and 
ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement,  as  specified  in  the  LARP.  Adequate  experienced  staff 
capacity for implementation of the LARP will be ensured by engaging an additional resettlement 
specialist. An external monitoring consultant, engaged by ADB, will monitor and validate LARP 
implementation.  A  community  liaison  group,  recently  established for  ADB’s  CAREC  Corridor  1 
investment  program,  will  assist  in  disseminating  information  to  displaced  persons  and 
communities along the road and in resolving grievances arising from project activities.
